Football.title: Where to watch Rangers vs Celtic: Kick-off time, team news and talkSPORT coverage for Old Firm contest
Football.content:
Where to watch Rangers vs Celtic: Kick-off time, team news and talkSPORT coverage for Old Firm contest

The Scottish Premiership title race is heating up, and it could take a huge twist this weekend as Rangers face Celtic.

The Glasgow rivals are the traditional powerhouses in Scotland, but this season, we could have a new champion.

3 For the first time in a while, the title race in Scotland is exciting Credit: Getty

Alan Brazil goes full Thomas Frank and drinks out of Rangers cup live on talkSPORT

It will be a three-way race with Hearts for the rest of the season.

The Edinburgh-based side have a four point lead over the Gers and are six ahead of the Bhoys.

However, Celtic have a game in hand on the two above them.

By the time this one gets going, Hearts would have already played Aberdeen, meaning their lead at the top could be extended.

But the winner in this Old Firm will get a huge boost to try and kick on to overtake Hearts and claim the title.

How to follow Rangers vs Celtic

This SPFL clash will take place on Sunday, March 1 and kick-off at Ibrox is scheduled for 12pm.

The game will be shown on Sky Sports Main Event and Football.

Sky Go customers will be able to stream the action on their laptops and mobile devices.

Alternatively, various NOW TV memberships can be acquired, ranging from days to the whole year. More information here.

Last ten Old Firms Premiership, January 2026: Celtic 1-3 Rangers League Cup, November 2025: Celtic 3-1 Rangers Premiership, August 2025: Rangers 0-0 Celtic Premiership, May 2025: Rangers 1-1 Celtic Premiership, March 2025: Celtic 2-3 Rangers Premiership, January 2025: Rangers 3-0 Celtic League Cup, December 2024: Celtic 3-3 Rangers (Celtic won 5-4 on penalties) Premiership, September 2024: Celtic 3-0 Rangers FA Cup, May 2024: Celtic 1-0 Rangers Premiership, May 2024: Celtic 2-1 Rangers

3 Celtic have lost back-to-back games and have a trip to Europe for the second leg against Stuttgart before the Old Firm Credit: Getty

talkSPORT will have updates throughout the afternoon as well, and talkSPORT.com will be all over it as well.

To tune in to talkSPORT through the website, click HERE for the live stream.

You can also listen via the talkSPORT app, on DAB digital radio, through your smart speaker and on 1089 or 1053 AM.

Rangers vs Celtic: Team news

The home side were without Dujon Sterling last time out due to a small injury, so it remains to be seen if he is fit.

Danny Rohl also won't be able to call upon Connor Barron and Bailey Rice.

Meanwhile, Ryan Naderi is likely to only be fit enough for the bench.

For Celtic, Martin O'Neil is without Arne Engels due to injury.

Auston Trusty was sent off in a 2-1 defeat to Hibernian at the weekend and will be suspended.

Kelechi Iheanacho is doubtful, and Callum Osmand is a long-term absentee.

3 O'Neil faces a bit of a selection nightmare Credit: AFP

Rangers vs Celtic: What has been said?

Gers legend Kris Boyd thinks if there is a loser at Ibrox, they would be out of the title race.

He said: “Whoever loses it, for me, is out of it, especially Celtic. I can’t see any way back for Celtic if Rangers have to get the victory.

“Yes, they’ll have that game in hand on a Wednesday night, but looking at it right now, Rangers now have to, or Celtic, have to win the game to keep in contact with, or close to, Hearts because I do think they’ll get the three points against Aberdeen on Saturday.

“So there’s going to be huge pressure on it. Rangers are at home. I don’t think Danny Rohl has any problem in getting his team up, well for an Old Firm game anyway, but at home, I don’t think there’ll be any problem.

“The fans will be right behind the team like we saw against Hearts. It’s probably as vocal as we’ve heard a Rangers fanbase for a number of years at Ibrox, so I don’t think that’ll be an issue.

"It’s over to the players to go and put on a performance that leads Rangers to getting three points.

“But I’ll say it again, I think whoever loses it is out it.”

Football.title: Chelsea, Newcastle and Man City in nightmare draw as Premier League clubs discover Champions League last-16 opponents
Football.content:
Chelsea, Newcastle and Man City in nightmare draw as Premier League clubs discover Champions League last-16 opponents

Chelsea and Newcastle avoided an all-English clash in a mouthwatering Champions League last-16 draw.

The Blues will instead face Paris Saint-Germain while the Magpies take on Barcelona.

3 Man City will take on Real Madrid in the latest instalment of their European rivalry Credit: AFP

Elsewhere, Manchester City drew Real Madrid yet again, while a tie against Norwegian minnows Bodo/Glimt was their other possibility.

For the other English sides, Arsenal landed Bayer Leverkusen, Liverpool will play Galatasaray and Tottenham were drawn against Atletico Madrid.

All six Premier League teams advanced through the league phase to make up more than a third of the sides left in the competition.

Newcastle were the only English club forced to go through the play-offs after Arsenal, Chelsea, Liverpool, Manchester City and Tottenham all finished inside the top eight and progressed straight to the round of 16.

3 The road to the final has now been mapped out in full

The Magpies eased their way through with a 9-3 aggregate victory over Qarabag.

First leg ties will take place on March 10 and March 11, before the second legs on March 17 and March 18.

The round of 16 schedule will be released later on Friday.

This year's final is set for May 30 at the Puskas Arena in Budapest.

Lucky Arsenal?

Premier League leaders Arsenal, who also topped the league phase with a perfect record, are currently favourites to go all the way.

Mikel Arteta's men are still competing on all four fronts domestically and in Europe with a historic quadruple still possible.

3 The Champions League last-16 sees Man City facing Real Madrid and Conor Gallagher returning to face Atletico Madrid with Spurs

Football.title: Lionel Messi hauled to the ground by pitch invader as security forced to intervene
Football.content:
Lionel Messi hauled to the ground by pitch invader as security forced to intervene

Lionel Messi was tackled to the ground by a rowdy pitch invader during Inter Miami's friendly clash on Thursday night.

The Argentina icon got on the scoresheet to help his side to a 2-1 victory over Independiente del Valle in their final pre-season fixture in Puerto Rico.

4 Messi got on the scoresheet for Inter Miami in an eventful friendly match Credit: Getty

As usual, Messi was the centre of attention, with the rescheduled game finally taking place after an initial date of February 13th was postponed after the star suffered a hamstring injury.

And while he is no stranger to huge fanfare, things went a step further in the 89th minute.

Messi situation

Play was briefly interrupted when several supporters charged onto the pitch, desperate to get close to Messi.

With this is a regular occurrence for the 38-year-old, he duly signed the shirt of one, whilst another managed to grab a selfie with him.

But the situation soon got out of hand when a topless fan sprinted towards Messi and wrapped his arms around him.

This sent his security guard into action, who brought the pitch invader down, but inadvertently took Messi with them.

Fortunately for all involved, the Inter Miami skipper emerged unscathed, who looked bemused as he got back on his feet.

After the fan was led away by security, the fixture resumed with a couple of minutes of stoppage time, as the MLS outfit saw out the win.

Messi had been introduced in the 43rd minute with the score at 1-1, before netting the winner in the 70th minute from the penalty spot.

And the pitch invasion wasn't the only incident in the eventful fixture, with kick-off also being delayed due to a kit clash.

4 A shirtless fan charged onto the pitch and headed straight towards Messi Credit: LOJA

4 The situation then escalated when the pitch invader tackled Messi to the ground Credit: LOJA

Both teams had emerged wearing black strips, making it almost impossible to tell between them.

However this was soon resolved, allowing the eagerly-awaited clash to get underway an hour later than planned.

Has the MLS season already begun?

Inter Miami travelled to Puerto Rico for the midweek friendly despite already starting their league campaign last weekend.

Messi's side got their MLS Cup title defence off to a disappointing start, as they were beaten 3-0 by LAFC.

The match saw two of the MLS' biggest stars meet on the pitch, with Heung-Min Son coming out on top with the California side.

Goals from David Martinez, Denis Bouanga and Nathan Ordaz sealed a comfortable victory for the hosts in front of a 75,673 crowd.

4 Messi was unable to get on the scoresheet as Inter Miami lost their MLS opener Credit: Getty

This marked the second-highest attendance in MLS history, with fans flocking in their numbers to the LA Memorial Coliseum.

It proved another eventful night for Messi, who had to be held back by Luis Suarez after the final whistle, seemingly furious with the officials

The David Beckham-owned franchise will look to bounce back in their next match on Sunday, against Florida rivals Orlando City.

Football.title: Monaco coach Djimi Traore reveals big clubs ‘keep calling’ him about Tottenham target
Football.content:
Former Liverpool defender Djimi Traore waxed lyrical about Monaco star Magnes Akliouche on talkSPORT Breakfast on Thursday morning.

Akliouche has been a revelation for the French giants this season, and marked his 24th birthday with a goal in Wednesday's Champions League playoff second leg stalemate with PSG.

2 Akliouche is one of the most promising creative players in France Credit: AFP

While Sebastien Pocognoli's side crashed out of the competition 5-4 on aggregate, a result that saw the defending champions progress to the round-of-16, the France international has caught the attention of a number of heavy hitters following his assist last week and goal in midweek.

Tottenham were credited with an interest in Akliouche over the summer, and again in the January transfer window, but opted against making a move for the creative star.

And Traore, who is now the manager of Les Monegasques' academy side, has revealed that he is fielding calls from heavy hitters that enquire about the club's academy product.

The main Mon

"He's a fantastic player, you know," Traore said on talkSPORT Breakfast with Alan Brazil and Gabby Agbonlahor.

"Some people call me about him, you know, even last year, you know, from the top club. And I always recommend the club to pick him because he's a top talent. He's only like 24.

"And he's not hit the ceiling yet. So he's very good on the ball, very technical. He can create chances, he can score goals. He has good pace.

"Now, what we need from him, because he's a young player, is to be more consistent. But if you play on the team, you know, that keep the ball more and stay more in position, you can see like all his best attributes."

Akliouche isn't the only promising star to recently come through the Monaco ranks to make the first team.

Eliesse Ben Seghir, Chrislain Matsima and Soungoutou Magassa all featured for the senior side before respective moves to Bayer Leverkusen, Augsburg and West Ham.

Monaco's famed academy

The academy also produced the likes of Thierry Henry, David Trezeguet and current Real Madrid star Kylian Mbappe.

2 Mbappe is one of a number of global superstars to have come through the Monaco ranks Credit: Getty

Traore went on to discuss the club's youth system with Brazil and Agbonlahor, adding: "Yes, we have a very, very good pathway, you know, just like the way we recruit players, you know, and the way we develop players.

"That's one of the reasons why I'm in Monaco. My second year there, I can tell you I coached some very, very talented players.

"But now the hard part for them is to be patient, because most of them, they want to go and play in the third team very, very early.

And they don't understand like it's a step by step.

"So that's what's the hard part for me as a coach with the B team, is to keep the guys motivated and keep the guy working every single day to go through in the first team.

"Because at the end of the day, when you go through in the first team, you've been there before, you want to play straight away. Sometimes you need patience.

"And that's why like the young generation, some of them are not very patient. And some of them, you know, it makes the wrong choice."

Monaco were unfortunate across both Champions League legs against PSG having been reduced to 10 men at a key point at the Stade Louis II and the Parc des Princes, losing Aleksandr Golovin and Mamadou Coulibaly, respectively.

They'll hope to quickly bounce back from their European disappointment and extend their Ligue 1 unbeaten run to six games with a third successive victory when they take on Angers this weekend.

News.title: I guarded Ian Huntley in jail… how slimy creep had to eat alone in his cell as inmates dreamed of ultimate ‘trophy kill’
News.content:
SERVED dismal meal trays in his cell and carted to tearful visitations with his parents on a golf buggy for protection, Ian Huntley’s life behind bars has long been a exercise in survival.

Now, as the monstrous murderer lies in a hospital bed fighting for his life following a vicious attack yesterday, one of his former guards has lifted the lid on the extraordinary measures prisons have been forced to take over the years to fend off bloodthirsty lags desperate for a ‘trophy kill’.





Journalist David McGee, who found himself guarding Huntley in a Category A jail during a daring undercover operation, said every possible precaution was taken to keep him safe from other inmates who wanted him dead.

But with prison overcrowding and staff shortages reaching a critical crisis, standards have slipped, leading to a huge surge in violence.

As part of a shocking investigation into the lax security of Britain’s jails in 2003, McGee landed a guard job and within days was placed on a rota of officers monitoring Huntley as he languished in a cell awaiting his trial at the Old Bailey for the brutal murders of schoolgirls Holly Wells and Jessica Chapman.

Ex school caretaker Huntley, then known behind bars as Prisoner JG5778 at Woodhill Prison in Milton Keynes, was on suicide watch and needed to be closely monitored by guards around the clock.

David recalled: “The police and prison management quite rightly feared Huntley would be killed from the very start of his stint in prison.

“From day one they were terrified he would be subject to some sort of trophy attack.





“They had good reason to think that – he was the most hated man in Britain at the time.

“And he was surrounded by some of the country’s most depraved and dangerous criminals who knew they were never getting out of prison anyway.

“Attacking Huntley would have been seen as a badge of honour.

“Whoever pulled it off would have been rewarded not just with treats like tobacco from the other inmates, but more importantly, the prestige.”

Guarding Huntley at Woodhill was a popular duty as warders would earn overtime, called Extra Gratuity Payments.

But it was gruelling work as the killer was locked in solitary confinement in his own individual cell block, far from any other lags.

David explained: “None of the other inmates could get anywhere near Huntley at that time, we had to make sure everyone else was kept well away.

“He was considered the very highest level of risk, the most vulnerable of all the prisoners.

“Huntley was given a level of protection that was not even afforded to police officers or paedophiles, who are generally considered extremely vulnerable because they tend to be the people who are most despised by other prisoners.”



Part of McGee’s job was escorting Huntley to and from his cell in a special golf buggy, because he would have been exposed for too long if he had walked.

He was given his own individual room for meetings – even though he did not get many visitors, apart from his parents and lawyers.

“Huntley was certainly never allowed near the canteen – all his meals had to be delivered to him on a tray,” David added.

“He was not allowed to mix and mingle at all.”

Speaking to The Sun’s Meeting The Monster series, David said the cocky killer’s mask slipped during one emotional visitation from his parents.

He explained: “I was in the room while he spoke with his parents, and although I was not close enough to hear what they were saying, it was clear his parents were very upset too.

“By the time they left they were absolutely wrecked. I put my hand on Huntley’s shoulder to steer him back to the buggy.

“It was only a distance of about 100 yards back to his cell but I was told he had to be driven both ways.



“He was bawling his eyes out, the meeting had clearly been deeply traumatising for him.

“Afterwards it took him quite a while to settle down. It was an astonishing day.”

With jails now operating at more than 99 per cent capacity, standards in prisons across the country have inevitably plummeted.

McGee tells us: “I’m not remotely surprised by this latest attack.

“Complacency has set in and I know that staff have had no choice but to become more relaxed.

“Huntley is one of the country’s most famous prisoners, it would still be considered a badge of honour to attack him – or worse.

“Anyone who managed it would be hailed a hero by the other inmates.”

I found him quite slimy and I’m sure he believed he would get away with his vile crimes

On Thursday it emerged that Huntley had been rushed to hospital after being found in a pool of blood following an attack allegedly by triple killer Anthony Russell, 43, at HMP Frankland in County Durham where he is serving a life sentence with a minimum of 40 years.



In 2011, a prisoner who slashed Huntley’s throat with a makeshift knife was jailed for life.

Damien Fowkes was sentenced to a minimum of 20 years for the attempted murder of Huntley after inflicting a wound seven inches long on the Soham murderer’s neck. The court was told it was only “good fortune” that the weapon missed anything vital.

Huntley had been convicted along with his girlfriend Maxine Carr, who knowingly provided him with an alibi during the search in August 2002.

Efforts to locate the missing girls in the 13 days after they disappeared have been described as the most extensive in British history as 400 cops were assigned full time to the case.

Huntley was arrested when cops discovered charred pieces of the red Manchester United football shirts both girls had been wearing when they disappeared.

News.title: Monster jailed for beating girlfriend to death after starving her to just 7st in campaign she compared to The Shining
News.content:
A MONSTER has been jailed for beating his girlfriend to death after starving her to just seven stone in a horrific abuse campaign.

Stephanie Blundell, 46, compared Tony Devenport’s rages to The Shining following a doomed holiday to Slovakia.





The former company executive was discovered lifeless on a blood-soaked mattress by her dad Phil Blundell just 11 days after returning to the UK.

Devenport, 57, had been found wandering around the flat in ”an intoxicated daze”, saying : “I think she’s dead, I think she’s dead.”

Stephanie had more than 100 injuries and weighed just 48kg after Devenport kept her confined to their home in Chester for ten days.



Devenport has now been jailed for life with a minimum of 22 years after he was found guilty of murder following a trial at Chester Crown Court.

Jurors heard Stephanie was ”talented young woman” who had worked as a jet-setting marketing executive for luxury watch brand Tag Heuer.

But after she met Devenport in 2024, her life began to implode and the pair began to drink heavily.

Prosecutor Owen Edwards KC said: “When sober he was described in messages from Stephanie as a kind man.



“But when in the middle of a binge his behaviour scared Stephanie. The defendant was described as possessive angry and paranoid, and she wanted him to receive help.”

Devenport went to Priory clinic and eventually quit drinking but in May 2025 fell off the wagon during the couple’s trip to Slovakia.

After returning to the UK, Stephanie chillingly told a taxi driver: “He’ll batter me when we go in – if I go in there now, he’ll just punch me.”

The driver phoned police who arrested Devenport for assault but Stephanie asked that no action be taken against him.

She told officers: “He’s like full on serious like gunna murder me….but I mither him and I shouldn’t do that I am so sorry.”



In the days before her death, the couple booked into the Pied Bull Hotel in Chester for two nights in a bid to save their relationship but staff were called to a bust up and Devenport was thrown out in the early hours.

On June 20, 2025, Stephanie’s dad Phil went to the home after becoming concerned he had not seen her in ten days.

Recalling the horror, he told police: ”I hammered on the door and Tony came to the door quite quickly.

“He was in a right state, physically and mentally and he said, ‘I think she’s dead, I think she’s dead’.

“I said, ‘What do you mean, you think she’s dead?’ but he was weeping and emotional and just psychotic.



“He said, ‘She’s in there” and I go into the back bedroom, and it’s, it’s just a terrible, terrible sight. I knew straight away she was dead.

“She had been a beautiful girl but when I saw her, she looked like a zombie. Tony was behind me and I said to him, ‘I know she’s dead, you’ve killed her’.

”The apartment was covered in filth, beer cans everywhere. It was absolutely disgusting. I regret not breaking that door down earlier.”

Jurors heard Stephanie had 102 injuries to her body including to her brain, which contributed directly to her death and was consistent with blunt force trauma.

She had just been fed the vodka lollies and sugary treats, which left her emaciated at 48kg and in pain from alcohol abuse.



Devenport claimed he “just slapped her about a few times the night before” and blamed her injuries on pushing her on a mattress.

He said: “At trial, Tony Devenport admitted he slapped Stephanie Blundell two or three times excessively but could provide no explanation for the 102 injuries found on her.

“These included traumatic, recently inflicted brain injuries, fractures to both thyroid horns, often associated with strangulation or mechanical asphyxiation, and severe facial bruising.”

He said he repeatedly maintained Stephanie died “peacefully” due to her struggles with alcohol.

News.title: Massive landslide smashes through six-bedroom house leaving dad-of-three moments from death in miracle escape
News.content:
A DAD-of-three was moments from death when a huge landslide smashed through his home – thought to be caused by a Grand Designs-style development next door.

Accountant Tom Baker had just left his house on the banks of the River Wye in Herefordshire when hundreds of tonnes of earth struck the property.





His wife Suzanne, who was away with their three kids, aged 14, four and 18 months, at the time, said: “If we’d been in, as would have been normal any other Friday evening, we could have been killed.

“It smashed down the entire wall at one end of the house, which is where our living room is and that’s where we’d normally all be hanging out in the evenings.

“Luckily I was away with the children for a couple of nights on holiday and my husband had nipped out briefly.

”It is thought demolition work on a neighbouring property to create a new riverside superhome had undermined a 100ft-high bank behind the houses.

Mrs Baker believes it had weakened the strength of the towering bank above, triggering the landslide.

She said: “The developer and his team pulled up a number of trees both in the bank and at its footings, so a lot of its strength and stability would have been weakened as a result of that.

“I believe the demolition work they carried out must have made the whole structure unsafe and now we have paid the price for that.”



The gaping hole left by the landslide has left the living room and an upstairs office bedroom of their six-bedroom in Hoarwithy completely exposed.

Workmen have spent several days trying to shore up the property and protect the exposed end of the house from rain.

The devastated family have had to remove valuables and furniture from the building and seek temporary accommodation elsewhere.

Mrs Baker said: “It is very fortunate that none of us were at home when this happened, but it is heartbreaking to see our beautiful home where we’ve lived for 15 years reduced to this.

“It is going to take a long long time to fix it and even then we cannot be sure how stable the bank behind us is going to be. What if it collapses again?



“We’re now having to live in makeshift accommodation while we speak to our insurance company and work out where we go from here.

“This is all new for us and we have no idea what the future holds now. It’s incredibly stressful.”

The remains of the neighbouring detached house, which has not been occupied for more than two years, was bought by a private owner who was in the process of completing its demolition when the landslide happened.

The owner’s application to replace it with a modern four bedroom wooden home on stilts had been refused by Herefordshire Council.

Last night the architect behind this new development told The Sun that they did not know the reason for the landslide but said it was indicative of climate change across the UK.



He added: “No one can know why it happened.

“Climate change has dropped a vast amount of water on the UK and around the world.

“There had been a landslide at that site before that had damaged the house which was vulnerable and needed replacing.”

News.title: Coronation Street’s Frank Grimes’ fortune revealed as star leaves everything to second wife after his death aged 78
News.content:
EX-CORONATION Street star Frank Grimes was worth just over £125,000 when he died.

Dubbed “one of Ireland’s greatest actors”, Frank left his estate to his second wife.





During a recent reading of his last will and testament, it was revealed that the gross value of Frank’s estate was £387,326, but only £127,521 after deductions, which was left to his second wife Ginnette.

The Barry Connor actor in Corrie died aged 78 in August last year following a short illness.

He appeared in the cobbles for seven years and was actress Kym Marsh’s onscreen dad before leaving in 2015.

The TV favourite also appeared in Casualty, The Bill, Doctors and Mrs Brown’s Boys.



The granddad-of-seven also worked on the stage including a role in Shakespeare’s Hamlet and received a Tony Award nomination for best actor in his Broadway role in Borstal Boy.

Born in Dublin on March 9, 1947 he was thought of as “one of Ireland’s greatest actors.”

On announcing his death, the Irish Cultural Centre in London said he was “so warm hearted, full of Dublin wit and charm in abundance and he had a beautiful sparkle in his eyes.”

They continued: “We are so sad to have to say goodbye to Frank, but we are also so blessed to have known him, to have worked with him and seen him perform.



“We also send our condolences to all of Frank’s friends and loved ones – May Frank sleep easy now and Rest In Peace.”

Frank lived in south west London and married his first wife actress Michele Lohan in 1968.

They had two sons David – who sadly died in 2011 – and Andrew.



He had divorced and then married Ginnette Clarke in 1984 before having his daughter Tilly.

Andrew and Tilly were named as executors of the will.

The grant of probate read: “Francis Patrick Grimes, of Barnes, died on 1 August, 2025.

“The last will and testament was proved and registered before the High Court of Justice.

“The application has stated that the gross value of the estate amounts to £387,326, and the net value amounts to £127,521.”



Frank’s will was written in 2016, and states: “I direct that all my debts and funeral and testamentary expenses be paid as soon as is convenient after my death. I leave my estate to my wife Ginnette Grimes.”

THIS is the chilling moment a sword-wielding maniac covered in blood tries to bash his neighbour’s door in.

Horrifying Ring doorbell footage shows Jan Dziedzic launching a frenzied attack outside his flat in Belvedere, south east London.





It reveals the drunken 36-year-old bashing on his neighbour’s door after he downed brandy while making a Christmas cake.

Dziedzic, drenched in his own blood and wearing black headphones, swings a samurai sword during the terrifying ordeal on November 11 last year.

The Japanese culture enthusiast shouts: “Come on… You piece of s***! Go f*** yourself!”.

He then slams the corridor door shut and appears to retreat back inside his flat.

It is understood the 36-year-old was barely on speaking terms with his neighbour at the time.

Dziedzic told Woolwich Crown Court he had no memory of the incident and was mortified by the footage.

He was jailed for one year after admitting to charges of affray, criminal damage and possessing a bladed article in public.

Judge Ruth Downing said she was “troubled” by Dziedzic’s behaviour, and told the defendant: “You were covered in blood and, no doubt to your neighbours – decent human beings – this was an alarming sight.



“Your neighbour suffered genuine distress. Why should she have to go through that?”

The judge also encouraged Dziedzic to seek professional help upon his release.

This comes after we reported on the shocking moment a man knocked a woman out in a “serious” random attack.

Cops have urgently appealed for help identifying the man and released CCTV in their appeal.

Elsewhere, cameras caught the dramatic moment heroic passersby used a saw and garden brush to fend off machete-wielding thugs robbing a gold shop.



Video shows thugs clad in black with helmets and machetes breaking into a Turkish gold shop in London.

Members of the public attempted to prevent the suspects from fleeing, the force added.

News.title: Murdered toddler James Bulger’s grave vandalised AGAIN by sick yobs as his devastated mum begs for them to stop
News.content:
JAMES Bulger’s grave has been vandalised again by heartless thugs with his devastated mum pleading for the vile acts to stop.

Little James was laid to rest at Kirkdale Cemetery, Liverpool, in 1993 but sick yobs have desecrated his grave yet again.





On February 12, 1993 little James was led away by Jon Venables and Robert Thompson while his mother Denise was in a butcher’s shop at the busy shopping centre.

After being abducted the two-year-old toddler was tortured and murdered before being abandoned on railway tracks 33 years ago by the depraved duo – who were ten at the time.

It was a crime that shocked the nation but it hasn’t stopped sick yobs from vandalising his resting place once more.



Devastated mum Denise Fergus shared a post on social media showing the damage.

Photographs showed two headless stone angel statues, either side of a headstone – which featured a picture of James and was clearly engraved with his name.

The cherubs had been “smashed to pieces”, said the horrified mum.

Furious Denies said it was believed the vile attack happened at Kirkdale Cemetery at some point between 10am and 3.30pm yesterday.



A heartbroken Denise said she had been alerted by a message from a woman walking her dog and she then “rushed down” to the cemetery.

She said: “I need to find whoever done this to my son’s resting place

“I try to help as many families as I can with either justice campaigns or helping families through the charity I set up in his memory and some horrid b*****d has done this… to a baby’s grave! Really??”

Merseyside Police described the attack as “abhorrent and truly shocking.”

Inspector Chris Taylor said: “We are taking this matter extremely seriously and remain determined to find the person or people responsible.



“To vandalise a grave is completely abhorrent and it’s truly shocking to think that someone could commit such an appalling act.

“Officers attended the scene when the incident was first reported and we are supporting the family during our enquiries.”



Writing on Facebook, Denise added: “If anyone has any information please send it via the charity page James Bulger Memorial Trust or contact Merseyside Police and let them know if you have seen or heard something.

“We think this happened between 10am and 3.30pm today.

“Could you please share this post to make sure the person or persons involved are caught and prosecuted.

“I’m devastated someone could be so cruel and hurtful to My James.”

Venables and Thompson were found guilty of Bulger’s abduction and murder on November 24, 1993 – making them the youngest people to be jailed for murder in 250 years.



The monsters had poured modelling paint into his eyes, stoned him and clubbed him with bricks, before leaving him on the railway line to be hit by a train.

At 18 years old, Venables and Thompson were both released from a young offenders’ institution under licence in June 2001.

After intensive rehabilitation, the pair were handed new identities.

Thompson has not re-offended since being released on licence when he was 18 years old.

RECOMMENDED STORIES

But Venables has been recalled to jail twice since he was first released in 2001 for possessing indecent images of children.



Venables’ new identity has been changed twice after he told friends he was a convicted murderer.

News.title: Mum-of-three who vanished 24 years ago is ARRESTED days after she’s found living secret life
News.content:
A MUM-of-three who disappeared without a trace in 2001 has been arrested just days after she was found alive and living a secret new life.

Michelle Hundley Smith, now 62, was taken into custody in North Carolina on an outstanding warrant dating back to the year she vanished.





The decades-old warrant stems from a drunk driving charge filed on November 11, 2001 – just weeks before she disappeared.

Authorities say she failed to appear in court in December 2001, and the warrant remained active for nearly 25 years.

She was arrested on Wednesday, posted a $2,000 bond and is scheduled to appear in court there on March 26.

Smith’s arrest comes days after detectives tracked her down last Thursday at rural North Carolina community following a tip.



Deputies said she was found “alive and well” and at her request, her exact whereabouts were not released.

Neighbors said she had “been here for years and years” and mostly kept to herself.

Authorities say she left her husband and three children just before Christmas in 2001 and never contacted them again.

Smith was 38 when she left her home in Eden, NC, on December 9, 2001.



She had told her family she was heading to a Kmart in Martinsville, Virginia, for Christmas shopping, but never returned.

Her forest green 1995 Pontiac Trans Sport van was never recovered.

For nearly a quarter century, her disappearance haunted her family and baffled investigators.

Authorities said Rockingham County Sheriff Sam Page told investigators Smith left of her own accord, citing “domestic issues.”

But Sheriff Page later told Fox News the sheriff’s office had no prior domestic violence reports on file.



District Attorney Katy Gregg, who serves Caswell and Rockingham counties, said her office will not pursue charges related to Smith’s disappearance.

“I support their decision,” Gregg said after meeting with investigators.

In interviews after resurfacing, Smith claimed she had no idea her family had spent decades searching for her.

She told the Daily Mail: “I know that I made the news, but I honestly 100% never knew that I was loved or wanted.

“When I left, the mental state I was in, I thought it was my only choice.



“I was just not in the mental state to stay. My children were not abandoned, they were left with their father to care for them.”

Smith added that she has reconnected with her middle daughter, Amanda.

“She has forgiven me and she has said I’m human like anybody else is,” Smith said.



The mum said learning of the years-long search left her devastated.

“I honestly believed I didn’t matter,” she said.

“When I found out, it broke me. That’s why I’m trying to rebuild something with her, because what she did, shows how much I really was loved.”

She insisted she never saw missing person flyers, billboards or news reports, adding: “If I’d had any idea, I would have already called them and let them know I was ok.

“I didn’t have to go back if I didn’t want to. I could have just let my kids know I was ok.



“I would have never put them through that, I thought leaving them was better for them.”

New details have also emerged about the troubled months before she vanished.

Smith had reportedly struggled with alcohol abuse and had been fired from a veterinary practice for “drinking on the job,” according to her daughter Amanda in a 2018 interview on The Vanished Podcast.

“My dad didn’t like the fact that my mom hid her drinking,” Amanda said.

“I knew about it, and I was the only one and I felt, you know, I was young and I felt obligated not to say anything to betray my mom.”



Court records show Smith had been arrested for driving under the influence just one month before she vanished.

Authorities say her failure to appear in court triggered the warrant that remained active for decades.

Sheriff Page has said it was not unusual for Smith to leave home for periods of time, which reportedly explains why she was not officially reported missing until New Year’s Eve 2001 – more than three weeks after she disappeared.

In a separate 2024 post before her mother was located, Amanda wrote: “All I do know is that you left a hole in people’s hearts!”

Smith’s sister, brothers and extended family have also expressed relief she is alive.



Her brothers told the Daily Mail: “We want Michele to know that we are so glad she is alive, we love her, we are not mad at her, all is forgiven.”

RECOMMENDED STORIES

Smith’s mother died in November after spending nearly 25 years searching for answers.

The district attorney’s office has said it is conducting a full review of the case.

News.title: Moment tourist runs naked in Thai hotel after 'attack by Sin City sex workers'
News.content:
Moment tourist runs naked in Thai hotel after 'attack by Sin City sex workers'

A tourist was seen on CCTV running completely naked through his hotel in Pattaya, Thailand, after he was allegedly attacked and robbed by sex workers in the 'Sin City'

View 4 Images The tourist ran naked through his hotel after he was allegedly attacked and robbed (Image: Asia Pacific Press via ViralPress)

A holidaymaker was spotted running around a hotel naked after he was allegedly robbed by a sex worker in a popular holiday destination.

‌



The tourist, who has only been identified as a Chinese man, took the transgender woman back to his room in Pattaya, Thailand. But just 10 minutes later, the man was captured on CCTV running down the corridor completely nude.

‌



He alerted a receptionist and said two women attacked him and stole 10,000 baht (£238.66) as well as an iPhone 15 Pro Max from his room. Police later traced one of the suspects named as Atikhun Mueangmungkhun. The 20-year-old was found in a room share, alongside four other women. She was arrested on February 26.

‌



Woman trapped in 90C water after horror explosion as doctors forced to amputate READ MORE :

View 4 Images The tourist was spotted in the hallway (Image: Asia Pacific Press via ViralPress)

Atikhun initially denied involvement, but later confessed when security footage clearly showing her face was presented. She was charged with 'robbery at night with a weapon, or by two or more persons acting together to facilitate the theft or escape with the property'.

Police Captain Assada Jarusombat of Tourist Police Division 1 said: "We presented evidence from security cameras and the phone taken from the Chinese tourist, which served as incriminating evidence that led to the issuance of the arrest warrant.The suspect surrendered due to the evidence against her, and was handed over to the inquiry officer along with the seized items for further legal proceedings."

‌



View 4 Images Police arrested her following the incident (Image: Asia Pacific Press via ViralPress)

The arrest comes amid a spate of violent attacks on tourists in the resort town known as Sin City. On February 24, a cross dresser named Fuengfah allegedly stole 20,000 baht before attacking Korean holidaymaker Kim Sangyul, 46, when she was confronted.

The sex worker was also implicated in a street attack on German tourist Markus Santl, 55, just a day earlier. On February 17, a Chinese tourist was allegedly beaten and robbed by three sex workers when he refused to pay the extra fees they demanded.

‌



On February 11, a group of transgender women had a mass street brawl with British tourists over alleged missing money in the same city. Locals said violent incidents were common in the city, especially around the town's Beach Road, the two-and-a-half-mile strip packed every night with street sex workers waiting for customers.

View 4 Images Atikhun Mueangmungkhun was arrested over the alleged robbery (Image: Asia Pacific Press via ViralPress)

Despite regular crackdowns by police, sex workers flee upon seeing approaching officers, only to later regroup when patrol units leave. Exasperated officers even admit privately that there is little they can do to solve the issue.

Article continues below

Pattaya has become the country's flagship tourist destination, fuelled by the allure of bars, massage parlours, and cheap sex. However, the region is now often seen as tarnishing the wider image of Thailand as a family-friendly holiday destination with stunning beaches, food and a rich history.

News.title: Spring statement 2026: What it could mean for you and your money
News.content:
Spring statement 2026: What it could mean for you and your money

The spring statement on March 3 is being sold as a "low key" event by the government but there is still plenty to look out on the state of the economy and people's finances

View 3 Images Chancellor Rachel Reeves will likely use her spring statement to herald Labour's achievements and basis for growth (Image: Bloomberg, Bloomberg via Getty Images)

Given Labour’s bruising defeat in the Gorton and Denton by-election, the party won’t want to make matters worse.

‌



Events often come thick and fast in politics, and so it is that next Tuesday will bring another in the form of the spring statement. In light of its standing in the polls, Labour is keen that it doesn’t become yet another stick for opponents to beat it with.

‌



Unlike a Budget, the spring statement is supposed to be a much more muted affair, And Tuesday’s occasion could be very much that, with signs in advance it will be a “low key” moment.

‌



Ensure our latest headlines always appear at the top of your Google Search by making us a Preferred Source. Click here to activate or add us as your Preferred Source in your Google search settings.

View 3 Images Rachel Reeves is keenly aware that tackling the cost of living squeeze remains a ket concern for voters (Image: Alishia Abodunde, Getty Images)

Keir Starmer breaks silence after Labour defeat in Gorton and Denton by-election READ MORE :

Ian Huntley's alleged attacker named and pictured as child killer fights for life READ MORE :

Labour is desperate not to rock the boat ahead of the all-important May elections. But expect Chancellor Rachel Reeves to use the statement to highlight Labour’s many achievements in government so far, and to impress upon voters - and financial markets - that stability is the watch word, and there are plenty of reasons for optimism.

‌



The Institute for Fiscal Studies (IFS) warned there could be “indications of potential risks looming on the horizon – risks which, if crystallised, could raise the spectre of another tough Autumn Budget.”

When is the spring statement, and how long will it last?

It will be delivered on Tuesday March 3. While the timing hasn’t been confirmed, it is likely to be shortly after midday. Whereas a Budget can last for an hour, reports suggest Ms Reeves could be done and dusted in 20 minutes.

‌



Will the spring statement mean tax rises, or any changes?

Ms Reeves has made clear she only wants to make major fiscal announcements on tax and spending once a year, at the autumn Budget. That doesn’t mean there won’t be tweaks or updates that will impact very many people. For example, at last year’s spring statement on March 26 Ms Reeves confirmed details of changes to benefits, although some were reversed later in the year. The Chancellor will be conscious not to announce anything that could be seen as a ‘stealth’ tax on working people.

What about changes to things like alcohol and cigarette taxes?

‌



We’re not expecting any new changes, beyond those confirmed in the last Budget.

View 3 Images Falling inflation could deliver a borrower boosting Bank of England rare cut as soon as March (Image: PA Archive)

What might the focus be on?

‌



Much attention will be updated forecasts from the Office for Budget Responsibility.

The OBR’s role was thrown into the spotlight at the last Budget when, in a major blunder, it accidently released its assessment in advance of Ms Reeves delivering her speech. Following a review, the OBR’s forecasts are expected to be published on the gov.uk website, rather than the OBR’s own. The watchdog won’t be updating where it thinks the government stands on its borrowing and debt targets.

Much attention will be what the OBR’s estimates for growth and living costs. The UK economy grew just 1.3% last year, and experts think it won’t do much better - if at all - in 2026, as it stands.

‌



But things are looking up when it comes to living costs, or at least not as bad as they were. Inflation has eased a lot, and rose at 3% in the year to January. Expect the OBR to predict a further slowdown in the months ahead, helped by the £150 off energy costs announced by Ms Reeves in the Budget.

Other updates to look out for are the jobless total, which has been rising slowly and hit a near five year high of 5.2% in the three months to December. There could also be revisions to the OBR’s forecasts for net UK migration. The IFS said, however: “We do not expect a major revision.”

What it mean if I’m a borrower?

‌



Cooling inflation paves the way for another interest rate cut from the Bank of England, which is tasked with getting it back to 2%.

The Bank’s Monetary Policy Committee next votes on March 19, with growing expectations it will cut its base rate from 3.75% to 3.5%. That’s good news if you’re a mortgage or other borrower on a variable rate. Forecasts of slowing inflation and lower government borrowing costs could also feed through to cheaper mortgages for those taking out fixed rate mortgages. Ben Thompson, director of home moving strategy at Mortgage Advice Bureau, said: “For homeowners currently on a fixed rate mortgage, the statement itself is unlikely to trigger immediate changes to monthly repayments. “However, the broader economic outlook it presents can influence where mortgage rates move in the months ahead.”

What does it mean if I’m a saver?

‌



The flip side of lower costs for borrowers is lower returns for savers. If the direction of travel for borrowings costs is downwards, savers should expect deposit rates to also keep falling. That said, all lenders have different priorities so will hunt around for the best rates on offer. The difference between leaving your nest-egg in a paltry paying easy access account or a best buy savings account could be stark.

What might Ms Reeves announce?

Some experts have suggested she might look at targeted help in some areas.

Article continues below

Grant Slade, economist at Morningstar, said: “One issue that the Chancellor may choose to focus on is youth unemployment. If the government’s implied fiscal headroom improves, the government could increase funding of initiatives such as its “Youth Guarantee” scheme – a £820 million existing funding package aiming to create 350,000 new training and work experience opportunities for young people.”

News.title: Evil paedo who showed 'no remorse' found dead just weeks into prison sentence
News.content:
A paedophile was found unresponsive in his prison cell less than three weeks after being jailed for his horrifying crimes.

An inquest into the unexplained death of Paul Withnell opened today. Withnell, from Powys in Wales, was found unresponsive in his prison cell after being jailed for historic rapes.

Last month he received a 21-year prison sentence following his conviction for a string of child sexual offences dating back to the 1980s, Wales Online reports. His cellmate discovered the 74-year-old unresponsive in his bed in Bridgend's Parc prison on February 5, Pontypridd coroners' court has heard.

Ensure our latest headlines always appear at the top of your Google Search by making us a Preferred Source. Click here to activate or add us as your Preferred Source in your Google search settings.

A provisional cause of death was recorded as "pending further investigation" following a post-mortem at Royal Glamorgan Hospital.

A Cardiff Crown Court judge said Withnell had shown "not one single shred of remorse" before jailing him for the string of offences which took place from 1981 to 1990 when Withnell was aged 30 to 39.

Withnell, of Broad Street, New Radnor, Presteigne, pleaded guilty to making indecent photos of a child but denied other offences. He was convicted of four counts of raping a girl aged under 16, six counts of gross indecency with a girl aged under 14, and eight counts of indecent assault of a girl aged under 16 following an eight-day trial.

The judge said that Withnell had been left with "little choice" but to admit to making indecent photos of a child after police uncovered 132 photos of his victim. Hywel Davies, representing Withnell, said his client had no previous convictions and suffered with poor health.

Sentencing Withnell to 21 years in prison, Judge Eugene Egan told him: "You caused unspeakable hardship, misery and upset and decades of emotional pain." Two thirds of which was to be served in custody.

Coroner Andrew Morse said the date of inquest would be fixed pending investigations.

News.title: Breaking '8am to 1pm' Saturday rule could trigger £5k fine in UK spring 2026
News.content:
People across the UK are being reminded of a weekend 'rule' ahead of spring, as many homeowners are set to start house improvements and DIY garden renovations. Typically, the peak time homeowners begin working on their properties is between March and May, according to Zoopla.

When the weather gets warmer, people usually become more interested in home improvement projects, making it the most active time to start renovations. After a cold and wet winter, spring is often seen as the ideal time to breathe life back into your home and garden. However, anyone planning any major construction work in a built-up residential area should be mindful of a 'noise rule'.

Across the UK, the standard time for noisy construction work to begin is between 8am and 6pm on Mondays through to Fridays, and between 8am and 1pm on Saturdays. Noisy work outside of these times could put you at risk of getting in trouble with not only your neighbours but also your local council. Noisy work is also generally expected to be avoided completely on Sundays and Bank Holidays.

Although there is no single nationwide rule, most areas across the UK operate under expectations set by local councils via the Control of Pollution Act 1974. Local councils have the power to impose significant penalties for violations of noise restrictions, including issuing a Noise Abatement Notice.

A Noise Abatement Notice is an official document issued by a local council when it considers a noise to be a "statutory nuisance" under the Environmental Protection Act 1990. This can include things like really loud music, parties, or barking dogs. The notice tells the person to stop or reduce the noise, usually right away.

Failing to comply with a Noise Abatement Notice for loud building work could result in a hefty fine. For commercial construction projects that fail to comply with a noise restriction notice, fines may reach up to £20,000. Domestic or DIY noise complaints may result in fines of up to £5,000.

Councils often first issue a Fixed Penalty Notice (FPN), which allows the offender to pay a fine rather than face prosecution. FPNs can be up to £110 for dwellings or £500 for licensed premises. However, in extreme cases of non-compliance with a notice, fines can be unlimited.

The 8am start time is a standard across much of the UK, but local councils have the freedom to set their own permitted hours and enforcement measures, meaning the rule is not legally binding in exactly the same way everywhere. For instance, Westminster City Council in London allows noisy construction from 8am to 6pm on weekdays but strictly prohibits it on Sundays and Bank Holidays.

Elsewhere, Birmingham City Council imposes similar times, including keeping 'noisy construction work' to 8am and 1pm on Saturdays. Spelthorne Borough Council says: "Contractors may work outside these hours if they are not causing any noise, i.e. painting and decorating." A large majority of councils follow the same protocols, but it is wise to check your local authorities' rules.

On Gov.uk, it says: "Councils can serve a notice on people carrying out construction or demolition works and tell them how the work should be carried out to avoid a potential statutory noise nuisance. The notice can specify any of the following: a noise level, the plant or machinery that can be used, the hours when work can be done and steps that need to be taken to minimise noise. Those failing to comply with the notice can be prosecuted and fined an unlimited amount, with further fines for each day that they fail to comply."

Some councils may permit 7.30am starts for certain commercial projects or in industrial zones. It is best to check your local council's website first before planning any major DIY projects for your home or garden.

It's important to note that 'quiet' work, which doesn't involve loud tools or machinery, may be tolerated outside the standard hours. However, this is often at the discretion of your local council or neighbours.

Many councils typically define 'noisy work' as any activity producing sound at a level likely to disturb nearby residents. This includes not just heavy equipment like jackhammers and angle grinders, but also hammering, drilling, sawing, heavy lifting using metal scaffolding, operating cement mixers, and even construction material deliveries that use lorries with reversing beepers or cranes.

Builders and DIYers are urged to check directly with their local authority for the precise working hours permitted. It is also key to check your council's latest guidance on applying for any necessary permissions or extensions.

News.title: 'My baby was left fighting for his life after catching Victorian bug at nursery'
News.content:
'My baby was left fighting for his life after catching Victorian bug at nursery'

Hannah Steppel's son Lenny-George fell dangerously ill and his mum ended up calling 999 before he was rushed by ambulance to hospital

View 3 Images A rash is a telltale sign of what can be a deadly condition (Image: Getty Images)

A mum has spoken of her horror after being told her toddler is thought to have caught a Victorian disease while at a nursery.

‌



Hannah Steppel's son Lenny-George fell dangerously ill and his mum ended up calling 999 before he was rushed by ambulance to hospital and was left fighting for his life with measles. The youngster had had his first MMR vaccine but was too young for his second at the time he fell ill.

‌



Hannah, 31, who works for a heating company said: “Measles is so dangerous, and I didn’t realise it before, I thought it was an illness from the Victorian times. I’d never known anyone to have it before my son got ill.”

‌

View 3 Images The tot was left fighting for his life (Image: Getty Images)

Huge surge as Measles cases up 21% in single week with virus epicentre revealed READ MORE :

The news comes as the Mirror this morning reported that a worrying surge in measles cases across England was revealed in official government stats and a leaked internal report suggest the real figures could be even worse.

‌



Officially there have been 158 confirmed cases of the virus this year to February 16 and of those two thirds were recorded in London, with the rest in the West Midlands. In the whole of 2025 there were 959 laboratory confirmed cases in England.

Worryingly the internal memo, marked "official sensitive" suggests that there have been 340 suspected cases in London this year. It also revealed that from January 20 to February 7 there were 34 confirmed vases in a single school in Enfield, with local health chiefs urging local parents to make sure their children are given the MMR vaccine.

They added that any child who contracts the virus is forced to isolate for three weeks and will not be allowed to return to school during that time.

Now, the mum from Sutton, London, is issuing a warning to parents. She told The Sun: “I’m hoping if people see how bad it can be, they will make sure to get their kids vaccinated.

“It’s not just your kids you’re putting at risk by not getting vaccinated, but other kids too." She added: "He had had his first dose of MMR, doctors said he wouldn’t have survived if he hadn’t had that."

News.title: Chilling Epstein deaths and dark threats from cellmate to lawyer and Hollywood star
News.content:
Chilling Epstein deaths and dark threats from cellmate to lawyer and Hollywood star

The Mirror takes a look at how Jeffrey Epstein managed to continue his shadowy web of influence for so many years - as conspiracies abound about the prolific sex offender

View 9 Images Questions swirl about Epstein and Maxwell and their crimes (Image: US Department of Justice/AFP via)

There have been a string of suicides and seemingly shady deaths among those associated with the Epstein Files.

‌



The disgraced financier certainly operated in an unusual orbit, with high-powered names of the great and the good littering millions of documents that have been made public - from phone and bank records, to photographs, BBM messages and emails.

‌



Appearing in the Epstein files does not mean that those people have committed any wrongdoing. But it is the shadowy nature of Epstein's dealings that has compounded a chilling sense of conspiracy and intrigue - where did his money come from, who really knew about and participated in his sex trafficking ring, and why are so many of those who accused or associated with him now dead?

‌



Even Epstein's own death is shrouded in mystery after a document in the files announced his passing the day before it actually happened. Many have claimed that the he did not take his own life in jail, as was officially recorded, but that he was murdered while awaiting trial on charges of sex trafficking minors. But as the apparent mastermind of the hideous operation, why would anyone want to kill him?

Ensure our latest headlines always appear at the top of your Google Search by making us a Preferred Source. Click here to activate or add us as your Preferred Source in your Google search settings.

View 9 Images Ghislaine Maxwell recently appeared before the House Oversight Comittee (Image: PA)

‌



Epstein and co-conspirator Ghislaine Maxwell have long been accused of keeping a list or black book of associates to levy as blackmail - claims Maxwell denied during an interview with the US Department of Justice last July. Hidden cameras were found in Epstein's Palm Beach house - one in a carriage clock - adding to suspicions that he made his millions by blackmailing his wealthy friends.

The impact of the files has been far-reaching. In the UK, Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor and Peter Mandelson have both been arrested and quizzed by police on suspicion of passing on sensitive documents to Epstein while in public roles as Trade Envoy and Business Secretary respectively. An email appearing to be sent by Maxwell confirms that a picture of Andrew taken with Epstein victim Virgina Guiffre was real - something the former duke has always denied.

The list of names is seemingly endless - Donald Trump, Richard Branson, Bill Clinton, Michael Jackson, Kevin Spacey, Sarah Ferguson and Elon Musk all feature. Even Steven Hawkins makes an appearance in a photo showing him reclining on a sun-lounger flanked by two bikini-clad women, who his family insist were his carers. Inclusion in the Epstein files is not an indication of guilt, nor of knowledge of his crimes.

‌



But many believe the files are merely the tip of the iceberg when it comes to the lurid workings of Epstein's operations. His victims have long claimed they were groomed while underage by Maxwell and recruited to give massages and sexual favours to Epstein and his friends. In the files, the youngest victim appears to be aged just nine.

One accuser told the FBI Andrew watched her being tortured as a schoolgirl at Frogmore Cottage in Windsor. The accuser claimed she was strapped to a table and "tortured with electrical shocks" by Maxwell, while a group of men watched. The former prince has denied any wrongdoing.

In separate claims, the alleged victim said she was between six and eight years old when she was "drugged at night and driven by my father, [redacted], to pedophile ring 'parties'."

‌



There are yet darker claims about cannibalism and satanic rituals - something that does not feature explicitly in the files. And for now, Maxwell is keeping her council, citing her fifth amendment right unless she is granted clemency. She is currently serving a 20-year sentence for sex trafficking.

But her silence could be all the more understandable given the fate of Epstein and the mysterious string of deaths.

Former Prime Minister Thorbjørn Jagland was reportedly hospitalised on Tuesday, February 24, just a few days after he was charged with serious corruption offences, linked to his association with the paedophile. Jagland was charged with "gross corruption" after newly released documents appeared to reveal a transactional relationship between the ex-PM and Epstein, between 2011 and 2018. Some Norwegian newspaper outlets have reported that he was hospitalised because of a suicide attempt, but his spokesperson denied this, citing instead stress.

‌



Here, The Mirror takes a look at the suicides and unexpecting passings that have plagued those associated with the scandal, many of whom tried to bring Epstein to justice...

Epstein death riddle

View 9 Images The scene of Epstein's death (Image: 60 Minutes/CBS)

Jeffrey Epstein's death inside a New York prison cell in 2019 ignited explosive theories that only spread further amid the mystery behind missing CCTV footage. On July 23, he was found in his cell with injuries to his neck and in a semi-conscious state.

‌



Officials quizzed his cellmate Nicholas Tartagilone, though an investigation cleared him of wrongdoing. Epstein had been returned to the security housing unit in the prison, where he was supposed to have a cellmate and be checked on every 30 minutes. But his cellmate was moved on August 9; the day before he died. Both guards who were assigned to check on Epstein fell asleep while on shift and falsified their records. And cameras in the holding area were said to be malfunctioned or were broken.

The Epstein Files included a draft of a formal statement announcing his death, which was dated a day before he was actually found hanged.

Maxwell herself said in an interview last August "I do not believe he died by suicide," but she called the idea that he had been killed to protect rich and powerful people "ludicrous," instead stating she believes that it was in her view "an internal situation" within the prison, saying: "In prison, where I am, they will kill you or they will pay - somebody can pay a prisoner to kill you for $25 worth of commissary. That's about the going rate for a hit with a lock today".

‌



A pathologist present at Epstein's post-mortem - and hired by Epstein's estate - has called for reinvestigation into the financier's death. "My opinion is that his death was most likely caused by strangulation pressure rather than hanging. Given all the information now available, further investigation into the cause and manner of death is warranted."

Virginia Giuffre

One Epstein's most high profile accusers, Virginia Giuffre died last April in Western Australia by suicide. At age 41, she left behind three children, who had been removed from her care. She was estranged from her husband, Robert Giuffre, and an intense legal battle has been launched over the fortune she left behind, with her sons arguing that an unsigned will is not valid.

View 9 Images Virginia pictured in hospital after the mysterious crash (Image: INSTAGRAM)

‌



Her relationship with her husband had been rocky. She met and fell in love with Australian martial arts trainer Robert when she was just 19, while training at a massage school in Thailand. Epstein had instructed her to bring a Thai girl back to the US with her, but instead, Virginia married Robert just 10 days after their first meeting, and made a new life for herself in Australia.

In 2015 when the family lived in Colorado, US, the police attended a domestic violence incident at their home concerning allegations that Robert had assaulted Virginia. In early 2025, after another incident, Robert was granted a restraining order against Virginia which prohibited her from seeing her children. No charges were filed.

After years of seeking justice for survivors, Virgina's powerful autobiography, Nobody's Girl, was slated for an October 2025 release date. Sadly, it was an occasion she never got to see.

‌



Just six months before, Virginia shared photographs lying bruised and bloodied in a hospital bed following an apparent collision with a school bus near Perth, Western Australia. She told how she had suffered kidney failure and been given just four days to live.

However, the Western Australia Police Force (WAPF) described it as "a minor crash" between a bus and a car north of Perth, clarifying that there had been no reports of any serious injuries. Meanwhile, John WA ambulance services have also reported that there are no records of any emergency response resulting in hospitalisation.

Virgina made a recovery but was found dead on her farm just a month later in an apparent suicide. Her father, Sky Roberts, told Piers Morgan that 'someone got to her' and there was 'no way' she would have killed herself.

‌



In December 2019, Ms Giuffre posted her own message which read: "I am making it publicly known that in no way, shape or form am I suicidal. I have made this known to my therapist and GP – If something happens to me – in the sake of my family do not let this go away and help me to protect them. Too many evil people want to see me quieted."

Jean-Luc Brunel

View 9 Images Film director Brett Ratner and Jean-Luc Brunel in a photo included in the Epstein Files (Image: Department of Justice)

Epstein's pal, modelling agent Jean-Luc Brunel, was found hanged in Paris prison cell in 2022.

‌



He had been detained for more than year, and was under investigation for suspicion of rape and trafficking of minors for sexual exploitation. Brunel was suspected of having been part of a global underage sex ring organised by late paedophile Epstein and had been originally indicted for the "rape of a minor over 15 years old". He also allegedly procured women and girls for the convicted sex offender.

Epstein had funded the founding of Brunel's US agency MC2 Model Management and Brunel was a cofounder of the French agency Karin Models.

He was found hanging in his cell at 1am. An investigating source said: "A night patrol found his lifeless body. A judicial enquiry has been launched, and early evidence points to suicide. There were no obvious fears for the prisoner's health and he was not on a suicide watch, having already been in prison for many months."

‌



Ruslana Korshunova

View 9 Images Ruslana Korshunova, pictured wearing Betsey Johnson, shot to fame in the mid-2000s before things took a tragic turn (Image: Thomas Concordia/WireImage.com)

Ruslana Korshunova was a rising star model who had been dubbed the Russian Rapunzel for her long, knee-length hair. Signed at just 15 in 2003, her career had seen her undertake campaigns for Marc Jacobs, Ghost, Nina Ricci, Christian Dior and Vera Wang.

Three years later she travelled to Epstein's private Caribbean island, Little St. James - one of many teenagers who flew on his private jet, nicknamed the 'Lolita Express' - it has been revealed in the Epstein files.

‌



On June 26 2006, someone wrote to Epstein saying: "I still have the white underwear we bought for Ruslana in St. John. Do you want me to give it to her?" to which he replied with an address and a time.

View 9 Images Ruslana's body was found in the street beneath her Manhattan apartment (Image: NY Daily News via Getty Images)

Ruslana died two years later in New York, after jumping from her ninth floor apartment just days before her 21st birthday. She was mentioned in correspondence between Epstein and his associates after her death, with someone writing to Epstein three years later, "Jeffrey, it is true that the agency failed to pay Ruslana Korshunova?"

‌



Epstein wrote to a redacted email account in 2010, "i hope you are having fun, two years ago „ ruslana a russian mod=l. died, mainly as a result of her boyfriends' belief in alternative m=dicine. vs real medicne" [sic].

Her mum, however, insisted that she would never have taken her own life. "She told me about her work problems about a year ago. She said that she wanted to quit the modelling career. Everything was fine with her recently though. If she had problems at work, she would have told me."

Steve Bing

View 9 Images Steve Bing pictured with his ex, Liz Hurley (Image: Internet Unknown)

‌



Hollywood movie producer Steve fell to his death from a Los Angeles skyscraper at the age of 55 in June 2020. The star, who fathered son Damien with ex Liz Hurley, had been an associate of Epstein's - but not one suspected of wrongdoing.

And before his death, his late girlfriend's aunt has claimed her niece had urged him to speak out.

Carrie Mitchum, aunt to Allexanne Mitchum - who died in 2019 - said in a Facebook post: "Steve also knew Jeffry Epstein. They weren't close and Steve didn't 'hang out' with him but a little over a year ago Allexanne convinced Steve to make a statement via his attorneys telling what he did know.

‌



"Allexanne was such a staunch advocate for victims of the sex trade and felt any information, no matter how insignificant it may seem, could prove to be useful. That's it. No big mystery or conspiracy here."

Allexanne died in 2019 of an accidental drug overdose, at the age of 28. Steve took his own life as the first anniversary of Allexanne's death drew near. Carrie claimed Steve and Allexanne had had a spat on June 26 2019, and she had gone to stay at a pal's house. They had made up, but before returning to their shared home she took what she believed to be a Xanax pill. It was laced with fentanyl, and caused her to overdose. She later died in hospital.

Steven Hoffenberg

Epstein associate Steven Hoffenberg was found dead at 77 in Connecticut in 2022. He had laid dead for a week with natural causes given as the reason. Hoffenberg was sentenced to 20 years in prison for a massive fraud scheme that saw thousands of people lose money to the tune of $460million in 1997. He alleged Epstein had designed the scheme and that they worked together closely on it. Before his death he alleged that Maxwell and Epstein "were 'taping' honey-trap videos of sleazy VIPs with underage girls for a cabal of deep-state blackmailing power brokers."

‌



Virginia Giuffre repeatedly claimed that Epstein videotaped his high-powered friends using hidden cameras in an attempt to get leverage on them - something backed up by the Mirror's historic investigation into hidden spy cameras in Epstein's mansions.

Carolyn Andriano

Carolyn, one of Epstein and Maxwell's victims, was just 14 when she met the pair in Florida. She died of an accidental overdose in 2023 at age 36, and had acted a key witness in securing the conviction of Maxwell.

She began working for Epstein as a teenager taking on the role of a cleaner and was abused by the sex traffickers for three years, leaving her with lifelong mental health issues, including drug dependency.

‌



According to ITV, her mother Dorothy said that her daughter would regularly come home with bite marks and bruises on her body - making up excuses about where they had come from.

Leigh Skye Patrick

Another victim, Leigh Skye Patrick, died at 29 in a West Palm Beach hotel room in 2017 in what was ruled an accidental overdose. Kathryn Smerling, a psychologist, told Fox News about her death that the "objectification" that Epstein's victims went through is "very traumatic", and that without proper therapeutic and family support, victims of trafficking will sadly often misuse substances as a way to cope.

Leigh had a twin sister called Selby Patrick, who told the Daily Mail two years after her sister's death that the root of Leigh's suffering had been Epstein, "[She suffered tremendously and it started with Epstein" Selby was quoted as saying, adding that her sister had "struggled with addiction since the time she met that guy".

‌



Alfredo Rodriguez

Epstein's former butler, Alfredo Rodriguez, died in 2014. Rodriguez had stolen Epstein's "Black Book" and tried to sell it in 2009 to an undercover FBI agent for $50,000. Instead of pocketing any cash for the address book filled with big names, he was slapped with an obstruction of justice charge for not handing it over as evidence.

He was sentenced to 18 months in 2012 and died on 28 December 2014 from mesothelioma.

Police, lawyers, and more

An officer who investigated Epstein, Joe Recarey, in his original conviction for child sex crimes died in 2018, five years after he retired. He died at the age of 50 and had been the lead investigator in the case, reportedly meticulously putting together evidence on Epstein's crimes. Epstein's cellmate - the last he had before his death in 2019 - died a year later of COVID-19. Efrain 'Stone' Reyes, is reported to have spoken to the federal investigation into Epstein's death not long before he died, and had been transferred out of the cell the night before Epstein's death.

‌



Threatened journalists

Journalist Vicky Ward has claimed that when she was profiling Epstein back in 2003 for Vanity Fair he threatened her whilst she was pregnant with twins. She told the Netflix documentary Filthy Rich, that he told her "it's going to be bad for you and your family" if he didn't "like" the piece. She also alleged that he threatened to "have a witch doctor place a curse on [her] unborn children".

View 9 Images Former Prime Minister of Norway, Thorbjørn Jagland, was rushed to hospital (Image: AFP via Getty Images)

She further claimed that her editor was "pretty spooked because he'd found a severed cat head in his garden [and] he also found a bullet on his doorstep". However, Vanity Fair editor Grayson Carter does not agree with this version of events, saying that the legal threshold for publication was not met at the time, and that he did not "trust" Ward.

Article continues below

Another contributing editor for Vanity Fair, John Connelly, who died in 2019, has said that Carter told him about the cat's head and the bullet. He said in 2003 Epstein was "torturing" Carter in an attempt to ensure there were no reports on the young women or girls. Connelly claimed that he pursued his own reporting into Epstein in 2006, but after Carter told him that he was afraid for the safety of his children, the journalist dropped the story.

For emotional support you can call the Samaritans 24-hour helpline on 116 123, email jo@samaritans.org, visit a Samaritans branch in person or go to the Samaritans website.

News.title: UK weather maps reveal 17C heat blast as England hotter than Benidorm next week
News.content:
UK weather maps reveal 17C heat blast as England hotter than Benidorm next week

Weather maps show temperatures could surge across the UK next week as parts of England could soon be warmer than holiday hotspots including Benidorm and Ibiza

View 3 Images Areas of deep red show where temperatures will rise well above the seasonal average (Image: metdesk)

Parts of the UK could be warmer than some of your favourite holiday hotspots next week as data suggests temperatures will surge well above the seasonal average.

‌



We have already seen temperatures creeping upwards this week, and while we are not out of the woods in terms of chilly conditions, there now appears to be sunshine on the horizon.

‌



The ECMWF weather model reveals temperatures could soon hit 17C in parts of England. Next Thursday, the maps show the mercury could rise to 16C at around midday in southern and eastern regions.

‌



Highs of 14C and 15C are possible quite widely across England around this time. However, conditions are expected to be notably cooler in Scotland, Northern Ireland, Wales and the far north of England.

View 3 Images Temperatures could rise to 16C at midday on Thursday (Image: metdesk)

England and Wales will be hotter than Zante as weather maps show heat blast date READ MORE :

UK weather maps show 18C heat spike as England hotter than Greece on Wednesday READ MORE :

Ensure our latest headlines always appear at the top of your Google Search by making us a Preferred Source. Click here to activate or add us as your Preferred Source in your Google search settings.

‌



Temperatures should keep rising though, as the maps show highs of 17C in eastern England, around Cambridge and Peterborough, at 6pm. Yorkshire, the Midlands and southern areas - including London - could rise to 16C.

In contrast, temperatures are only expected to rise as high as 15C in sunny Benidorm. The same is true for Ibiza.

And temperature anomaly maps for next Thursday have turned deep red over England. This indicates that temperatures will be well above the seasonal average.

‌



View 3 Images Highs of 17C are on the cards in the evening (Image: metdesk)

The Met Office says “plenty of dry weather” and “some sunshine” is to come. Its forecast for March 3 to 12 states: “Much of this period looks like being largely dominated by high pressure, especially towards the south or southeast of the UK.

“This will mean many places seeing plenty of dry weather with variable cloud amounts and some sunshine, the best of this towards the south or southeast, but perhaps with some fog overnight.

Article continues below

“However, frontal systems are still likely to affect the north and west of the UK at times though, maybe also briefly affecting other parts, bringing some rain and strong winds, and perhaps a little snow to the high ground in the north. Temperatures will be near or above normal, although patchy overnight frost is still likely at times.”
